intro: Oestlundorchis velutina, commonly known as the velvet orchid, is a rare and striking orchid species native to certain regions of Europe. It is characterized by its hairy, velvety leaves and showy, often greenish-yellow flowers that bloom in late spring. The plant typically grows in shaded, moist habitats such as woodlands and along stream banks. It is a terrestrial orchid that relies on specific mycorrhizal fungi for nutrient uptake, which is a common trait among orchids. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species in some areas.
